article.title: Introduction
article.section:
Entering Mathematics on a webpage
On the web HTML Forms are often used to obtain information from someone who is visiting a webpage. If a mathematical formula needs to be entered it is often more interesting what the formula means then in what form it is entered. For example x+1 is different from 1+x but is for most purposes equivalent.
OpenMath is a language in which it is possible to describe what a formula means, i.e. the semantics of the formula. It is an XML format, for which several interfaces are written (in Java) with Computer Algebra Systems. It is possible to call a computer algebra system to verify if a formula is equivalent to another. In particular, it is possible to test if the entered formula is equivalent to the correct answer of a question.
OpenMath, however, is not easy to enter by hand. This leads to the desire of a WYSIWYM (What You See Is What You Mean) input method. It would be preferrable if this input method could be coupled to the usual way of input in HTML: Forms. The logical element would be a TextArea, since the OpenMath would generally not fit on a single line.
The server can then process the Form correctly if the TextArea contains what the user means (in OpenMath) and the user will see the formula and not the OpenMath.

section.title: The MathDox Formula Editor
section.para: The MathDox formula editor is a web-based editor designed to enable entering mathematical formulas in webpages as described above. It has been developed at the Technische Universiteit Eindhoven as a means for students to enter formulas in an e-learning environment. Its main features are listed below.

itemizedlist.listitem: It has a two-dimensional WYSIWYM interface.
It can produce a semantic representation of the formula.
No plugins need to be installed in the browser to use the editor.
It can be easily integrated into existing HTML pages.
It is available under an open source license.

section.para: The editor is written in Javascript and uses the HTML5 canvas element in combination with jsMath sprite fonts to render mathematics.
Any questions or comments about the editor are welcome and can be directed at info@mathdox.org.

section.title: Future Work
section.para: Some things that would be nice to have in the future are:

itemizedlist.listitem: communication with services that translate to a native language of a computer algebra system or evaluate expressions
multiple line input (possibly with new editors)
create help for within the page containing the formulaeditor (or maybe a tooltip)
create example page with inline mathml display (not just the xml code)
